docs.lead_paragraph: It is hard to tell in the gnarled faces and hobbled steps of the men who come to Lyons Veterans Hospital here that they were once vigorous enough to fight at infernal places like Omaha Beach and the Ardennes Forest. Increasingly, they find themselves having to remind people of what they have been through and of the country's promise to provide them with decent medical care. On a recent morning, a stroke-hampered veteran was waiting in a wheelchair outside the office of Joseph L. Klapper, an ombudsman for patients. The gruff-voiced Mr. Klapper could be heard berating hospital administrators for delaying the veteran's application for home care and physical therapy.

headline.main: Veterans Fear a Budget Squeeze Will Hamper Hospital Care

docs.abstract: Veterans are anxious over freezing of veterans hospitals' budget through year 2002 and advent of managed care; retrenchment is already under way in hospitals in Northeast, whose budgets have been reduced to provide more money for growing numbers of veterans in South; changes are response to criticism that hospitals are underused, antiquated, mismanaged, ripe for abuse by veterans who were not wounded in combat, bloated with Congressional pork and twice as costly as private hospitals; Department of Veterans Affairs now assigns patients to a single primary care doctor and allows hospitals to recover money from private insurers for disabilities not related to military service; is seeking permission to recover money from veterans covered by Medicare and has even begun to rent its equipment to outside medical providers; photos (M)
docs.snippet: It is hard to tell in the gnarled faces and hobbled steps of the men who come to Lyons Veterans Hospital here that they were once vigorous enough to fight at infernal places like Omaha Beach and the Ardennes Forest. Increasingly, they find themselves...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Breast Examination Center of Harlem was designed as a cheery place, with toys to entertain patients' children and a billing policy as inviting as the atmosphere: mammograms, free of charge. But when the newly expanded center opened four years ago, its doctors were dismayed to discover that the women of Harlem were not banging down the doors to take advantage of their offer. ''We were running way under capacity,'' said Dr. Paul A. Marks, president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, which runs the Harlem center, ''and it was clearly not a question of cost. It's a mind-set.''

headline.main: Cultural Issues Pose Obstacles In Cancer Fight

docs.abstract: Federal health officials say that while African-Americans and other minorities have been slower than whites to benefit from national trend toward drop in new cancer cases and deaths, gaps may be narrowing soon as minorities increasingly take advantage of screening programs; black women are now having mammographies at same rates as white women, trend that began in 1992 (M)4

docs.lead_paragraph: In a setback for the White House, a Presidential advisory commission declined today to endorse the use of legislation to define and enforce the rights of patients who have been improperly denied health care benefits promised by insurance companies and employers. The panel agreed without dissent on the need for a renewed commitment to improving the quality of health care in America. But it left open the possibility that voluntary efforts could achieve that goal without new Federal laws.

headline.main: Presidential Panel Sees No Need for a Law on Patients' Rights

docs.lead_paragraph: A state appeals court ordered a nonprofit health maintenance organization in North Brunswick yesterday to make public the details of its relationship with a for-profit partner. Upholding the public's right to be informed about changes in the medical industry, the court said the HIP Health Plan of New Jersey had to release all documents on its affiliation with the PHE Healthcare Corporation of Roseland.

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans made its case to state regulators yesterday that it needed a large increase in the rates it charges people who buy their own insurance. But those same Oxford customers, armed with stories of sickness and fear of not being able to afford insurance, fired back in a public hearing, charging that the request was exorbitant. ''I have been able to resist public assistance until now,'' said Jim Lister, a 43-year-old AIDS patient from Manhattan who said Oxford's request may push him from private insurance. ''Depending on the outcome of this hearing, I may be forced to increase the public burden by one.''

headline.main: Subscribers Urge Regulators To Oppose Increase for Oxford

docs.lead_paragraph: BILLY BASCHNAGEL, an insurance broker in Austin, Tex., who specializes in coverage for high-risk activities, has a very clear idea of the wrong time for participants in adventure sports to start thinking about insurance. All he has to remember is how he felt sitting in a white-water raft ready to push off when the trip leaders explained the steps to take if someone fell out along the route.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sykes Healthplan Services Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Prudential Insurance Company of America's Prudential Service Bureau unit for $50 million in cash to expand its employee-benefits program administration business. Prudential Service, based in Louisville, Ky., is a company that manages employee health and welfare benefits for more than 600 major employers. The acquisition and others pending will create a company with combined annual revenue of $80 million and after-tax earnings of $3.3 million. Sykes Healthplan is a joint venture of Sykes Enterprises Inc. and the Healthplan Services Corporation, formed to make acquisitions in the employee-benefits administration business.

headline.main: SYKES AGREES TO PAY $50 MILLION FOR PRUDENTIAL UNIT

docs.lead_paragraph: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that Congress would probably pass health care legislation to protect the rights of patients this year, but he declared that the bill would not solve the problems of doctors and patients fed up with insurance companies. Mr. Gingrich made his forecast in a speech to the American Medical Association just five hours after President Clinton received strong support from the same audience for his campaign to pass a ''patient's bill of rights.''

headline.main: Warning and Wooing on Patient Bill of Rights

docs.abstract: Speaker Newt Gingrich says Congress will probably pass legislation to protect patients rights, speech to American Medical Associaiton; indicates he is not enthusiastic, holding bill will not solve problems of doctors and patients fed up with insurance companies; Pres Clinton earlier told AMA that bill is needed to require private health plans to provide patients with access to medical specialists and emergency room services, to protect confidentiality of medical records and to guarantee appeal rights for patients denied benefits; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that Congress would probably pass health care legislation to protect the rights of patients this year, but he declared that the bill would not solve the problems of doctors and patients fed up with insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton went before the American Medical Association yesterday to ask its help in pushing his ''patient's bill of rights'' through Congress. The doctors should support the President's plea because it helps patients. Even better, they will probably support it because it helps them regain some of the prerogatives they have ceded to powerful insurance companies. The President's prudent proposal, recommended by his commission on managed care, would assure patients that reasonable trips to hospital emergency rooms would be covered. It would protect the privacy of medical records and guarantee access to specialists. It would also guarantee the right of patients to appeal denials of care to an independent authority.
docs.abstract: Editorial backs Pres Clinton's call for bill to protect patient's rights; lauds bill, which would assure coverage for emergency room care, protect privacy of medical records, guarantee access to specialists and give patients right to appeal denials of care, for not pandering to special interest groups; calls for more review before opening up Medicare to early retirees and older laid-off workers (M)
